title: Diploma in Economics: Microeconomics
headline: Learn the essentials of microeconomics and how incentives and the actions of individuals shape the economy.
description: This free online economics diploma course teaches you about Microeconomics. You will learn about the important dynamics of microeconomics and get insightful answers to everyday questions such as why is customer service at your local restaurant is usually better than that of the cable company. Economics is much more than the study of numbers and graphs, this course will teach you how to apply economic thought to your daily life.
courseDescription:
First, you will learn about supply, demand, and equilibrium. You will study what causes shifts in supply and demand, what creates surplus, and how shortages occur. You will then look into taxes and subsidies and learn how the price system evolves and develops, along with the concepts of price ceilings and price floors. The course will also cover the concept of comparative advantage and the most common arguments against trade.

You will then learn all about competition in the market and the effects of monopolies. You will look into the monopolies that are created by patents in the pharmaceutical industry and how these patents affect research and development. You will look into labor markets, the value of education, and the concept of human capital. Finally, you will study the economics related to the consumer and learn about price discrimination, free rider, budget line, moral hazards, and much more.

The study of economics is not just for economists. By studying this microeconomics course, you will expand your business vocabulary and gain knowledge of how the markets work. You will understand market dynamics as a whole and learn how you can apply them to your organization, and will also boost your ability to analyze your own spending habits in the process. These are some great rewards, so check out the course today and learn something valuable and interesting in just a few short hours!

Start Course Now

  • Supply and Demand Terminology

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • The demand curve demonstrates how much of a good people are willing to buy at different prices.
    • A change in demand refers to a shift in the demand curve.
    • An increase in demand means an increase in the quantity demanded at every price. Similarly, a decrease in demand means a decrease in the quantity demanded at every price.
    • The supply curve shows how much of a good suppliers are willing to supply at different prices. For instance, oil suppliers in Alaska and Saudi Arabia face different costs of extraction, affecting the price at which they are willing to supply oil.
    • A change in supply refers to a shift in the entire supply curve caused by a change in costs such is a change in technology or input prices and so forth. 
    • Equilibrium quantity refers to when quantity demanded is equal to quantity supplied.
    • At equilibrium, the price is stable and gains from trade are maximized. When the price is not at equilibrium, a shortage or a surplus occurs. The equilibrium price is the result of competition amongst buyers and sellers.
    • Equilibrium price is the price where the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied.

  • Elasticity of Demand

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Office Hours: Elasticity of Demand

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Calculating the Elasticity of Demand

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Elasticity of Supply

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Elasticity and Slave Redemption

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Applications Using Elasticity

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • A demand curve is said to be elastic when an increase in price reduces the quantity demanded by a lot (and vice versa).
    • When the same increase in price reduces the quantity demanded just a little, then the demand curve is said to be inelastic.
    • Determinants of elasticity includes availability of substitutes, time horizon, classification of goods, nature of goods, and the size of the purchase relative to the consumer’s budget. 
    • Elasticity of demand is equal to the percentage change of quantity demanded divided by percentage change in price.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Commodity Taxes

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Who Pays the Tax

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Subsidies

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Wage Subsidies

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • A commodity tax is a tax on goods.
    • The more elastic side of the market will pay a smaller share of a tax.
    • The less elastic side of the market will pay a greater share of a tax.
    • When demand is more elastic than supply, demanders pay a smaller share of the tax and sellers pay a larger share of the tax.
    • When supply is more elastic than demand, buyers pay more of the tax.
    • Elastic demand means that demanders have good substitutes for the taxed good and so can escape the tax.
    • Elastic supply means that the resources used to produce the taxed good can easily be moved to other industries so they can escape the tax.
    • A tax generates revenue and creates a deadweight loss.
    • A subsidy is a reverse tax – the government gives money to consumers or producers.
    • A subsidy drives a wedge between the price received by sellers and the price paid by the buyers.
    • A wage subsidy costs the government money but increases employment and reduces welfare payments.

  • The main points of this module are as follows:
    • The price system allows for people with dispersed knowledge and information to coordinate global economic activity. 
    • The price system is emergent, and not the product of human design.
    • Prices are signals that convey information.
    • Markets link people and places all over the world. Markets are linked: geographically, across different goods, and through time.
    • Central planning is a single official or bureaucracy that is responsible for allocating limited resources.
    • The market collapses all the relevant information into a single number: the market price.
    • An increase in price signals that a product has become more valuable in other uses. This gives users an incentive to respond to the signal.
    • Speculation is an attempt to profit from future price changes. Speculation tends to smooth prices over time and increases welfare.
    • Futures are contracts to buy or sell specified quantities of a commodity or financial instrument at a specified time in the future at a price agreed on today.

  • Price Ceilings: Shortages and Quality Reduction

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Price Ceilings: Lines and Search Costs

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Price Ceilings: Rent Controls

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Price Floors: Airline Fares

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Why Do Governments Enact Price Controls?

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Price Controls and Communism

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • The main points from this module are as follows:
    • With a price ceiling, buyers are unable to signal their increased demand by bidding prices up, and suppliers have no incentive to increase quantity supplied because they can’t raise the price.
    • When the quantity demanded exceeds the quantity supplied, a shortage results.
    • The free market eliminates a shortage by letting the price rise.
    • Price ceilings result in five major unintended consequences: shortage of goods, low quality goods, long lines, search costs, and deadweight loss.
    • Rent controls are a type of price ceiling. Rent controls create shortages by reducing the supply of apartments available on the market. Rent controls also result in reduced product quality.
    •  There are search costs associated with rent controls, and they also lead to a misallocation of resources since apartments are not allocated to renters who value them the most.
    •  Price floors, when prices are kept artificially high, lead to several consequences that hurt the consumer. The minimum wage is an example of a price floor. 
    • Price floors lead to wasteful increases in quality and a misallocation of resources. 
    • Communism, a command economy, can be thought of as a system of universal price controls.
  • Price Ceilings

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Upon completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Define a price ceiling and a price floor.
    • Explain the unintended consequences of price ceilings. 
    • Describe types of price ceilings and price floors.
    • Explain why governments enact price controls.
    • Discuss how price controls relate to communism.

  • The main points from this module are as follows:
  • Three benefits of trade: 
    • makes people better off when preferences differ
    • trade increases productivity through specialization and the division of knowledge
    • trade increases productivity through specialization according to comparative advantage
    • Without trade, specialization is not possible.
    • Developing economies are less specialized.
    • Division of tasks = specialization.
    • Comparative advantage explains why people trade and what goods they should trade, too.
    • Comparative advantage can be applied to people, groups, and countries.
